subject: Compare each chunk of large objects when uploading
commit_message:
Compare each chunk of large objects when uploading

Previously, we compared the ETag from Swift against the MD5 of the
entire large object. However, the ETag for large objects is generally
the MD5 of the concatenation of the ETags for each segment, unless the
object is a DLO whose segments span more than one page of a container
listing. Rather than worry about ETags, just compare each chunk of the
segmented file. This allows the use of --skip-identical when uploading
SLOs and DLOs.

Additionally, there are several test-related improvements:
 * The default arguments for OutputManager are now evaluated on
   construction, rather than on definition, so that
   TestOutputManager.test_instantiation will succeed when using nosetest
   as a test runner. (See also: bug 1251507)
 * An account_username option is now available in the functional tests
   config file for auth systems that do not follow the account:username
   format.
 * CaptureOutput no longer writes to the captured stream, and
   MockHttpTest now captures output. These were polluting test output
   unnecessarily. (See also: bug 1201376)

Change-Id: Ic484e9a0c186c9283c4012c6a2fa77b96b8edf8a

subject: Add streaming algorithms and SLA to check for outliers
commit_message:
Add streaming algorithms and SLA to check for outliers

In the common.streaming_algorithms module, we add the base for the streaming
algorithms that take values from the input stream and compute certain
quantities needed for the benchmark results processing. These algorithms
should use constant memory and be able to scale.

Two streaming algorithms for computing mean and standard deviation are implemented.

There is also a new "max_outliers" SLA that checks for the maximum number of
outliers based on the mean and standard deviation of the durations, computed
using these new streaming algorithms. By default, the outliers are detected
only when the total number of iterations reaches 10 (can be configured).

Example:
  3.1 4.2 3.6 4.5 2.8 3.3 4.1 3.8 4.3 2.9 10.2 11.2 3.4

  has 2 outliers (10.2 and 11.2), so:
    {"outliers": {"max": 2}} -> PASS
    {"outliers": {"max": 1}} -> FAIL

Bonus:
  * Add gate testing of different SLAs with the Dummy scenario
  * Add samples for all SLAs
  * Fix detailed message for max_avg_duration

cleared but not when external_gateway_info is only updated which
implies the following sets of actions have different behaviors:

  neutron router-gateway-set router1 pub1 --disable-snat
  neutron router-gateway-set router1 pub2

enable_snat is False after the last command

  neutron router-gateway-set router1 pub1 --disable-snat
  neutron router-gateway-clear router1
  neutron router-gateway-set router1 pub2

enable_snat is True after the 2nd command resets the gateway AND

subject: libvirt/utils.py: Remove 'encryption' flag from create_cow_image
commit_message:
libvirt/utils.py: Remove 'encryption' flag from create_cow_image

Current code in create_cow_image inherits the 'encryption' property of a
qcow2 overlay from its backing file (also called base image).

However, importantly, even if the base image is encrypted, Nova has no
support for unencrypting it. So inherting the 'encryption' property
(from the backing file) serves no purpose. (Thanks Dan Berrange for
confirming this.)

Additionally, qcow2 encryption support is currently deprecated[1], with
plans[2] for a better future implementation, by upstream QEMU. Various
reasons (not least because of "flawed crypto") for it are noted in the
URL below, so it is reasonable to doubt if there are any serious users
of encyrpted images with its current design.

So, let's remove the 'encryption' flag from now.

[1] https://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/qemu-devel/2015-03/msg03433.html
    -- "block: Deprecate QCOW/QCOW2 encryption"
[2] https://www.berrange.com/posts/2015/03/17/qemu-qcow2-built-in-encryption-just-say-no-deprecated-now-to-be-deleted-soon/

Change-Id: If61ee881c21835e5d538d0eb12383b4b4ef2cfd4

subject: libvirt/utils.py: Remove needless code from create_cow_image
commit_message:
libvirt/utils.py: Remove needless code from create_cow_image

The said code was added (but commented out) by this commit
51441e369bb05e9cb9149ac9a7290fe541e3ed1a, which hoped to inherit
'preallocation' (of qcow2 metadata) property of a qcow2 overlay from its
backing file.

I.e. if you create a base image with 'preallocation' option:

    $ qemu-img create -f qcow2 base.qcow2 1G -o preallocation=metadata

And, create an overlay with the above image as its backing file and
provide the 'preallocation' option:

    $ qemu-img create -f qcow2 -b ./base.qcow2 -F qcow2 \
               overlay.qcow2 -o preallocation=metadata

it results in the below error:

    "qemu-img: overlay2.qcow2: Backing file and preallocation cannot be
    used at the same time"

QEMU upstream source confirms that, it is indeed an invalid combination
This behavior has not changed since the feature to preallocate qcow2
metadata was introduced originally[1].

So, it is safe to remove the commented out code, which is trying to do
supply an invalid combination of options to `qemu-img`.

[1] http://git.qemu.org/?p=qemu.git;a=commit;h=a35e1c17 --
    ("qcow2: Metadata preallocation", 17 AUG 2009)

libvirt/utils.py: Clarify comment in create_cow_image function

The below commit:

    commit 51441e369bb05e9cb9149ac9a7290fe541e3ed1a
    Author: Joshua Harlow <harlowja@yahoo-inc.com>
    Date:   Mon Sep 17 16:42:33 2012 -0700

        Inherit the base images qcow2 properties

introduced the behavior: when creating a qcow2 overlay from a base
image, the overlay image inherits properties like 'cluster_size' from
its backing file.

Explanation about it in the comment was not clear and had a URL to an
expired pastebin. Reword the comment with details (also remove an
outdated TODO item and an expired pastebin).

Some related notes:

Speaking with a QEMU block layer developer, Kevin Wolf, he clarifies
that qcow2 overlay images do _not_ inherit properties from its backing
file (assuming it had a non-default 'cluster_size' value). I.e. when
creating images with `qemu-img` tool, all options to it need to be
explicitly specified (except for 'size' of the disk image, if it isn't
specified).

Cases where inheriting the 'cluster_size' of an overlay image from its
backing file might be useful (thanks Dan Berrange, for the below
discussion):

  - Qcow2 default cluster_size has changed in the past (last in June
    2009, for version 0.11 -- confirmed with QEMU upstream) so depending
    on what specific version of QEMU people use to create images they
    upload (to Glance), it might affect things.
  - People might use a particular cluster_size that is matching some
    aspect of their storage. (Though, in practise, this seems to be very
    rare and might be useful in some really special storage
    environments.)
     - NOTE: A (global) default qcow2 'cluster_size' value of
       65536 bytes (i.e. 64 KiB) is used by QEMU when creating qcow2
       images.

subject: Fix sort column for event-list with nested-depth
commit_message:
Fix sort column for event-list with nested-depth

The non-nested-depth case can rely on the sort ordering from the
API response, but because we mangle together the response from
several event-list API calls in the nested-depth call, it's necessary
to ensure the sort ordering is correct by sorting on event_time.

Currently, we're sorting on the wrong column, because of the logic
which inserts a new column heading after we look up the index,
but switching to the right column still relies on the prettytable
sortby_index, which doesn't work with the "start" slice option,
if you want post-sort slicing (such as will be required to make
--marker and --limit work with the --nested-depth option, in a
later patch).

So, instead, pre-sort the list before passing to print_list, which
solves the immediate problem of wrong sort order, and provides
an easier step towards enabling marker/limit.

e-76c2-4ce3-95b6-d0db6cc8bdd0 do_request /opt/stack/glance/glance/
